p: Malaria is a disease of tropical and subtropical regions caused by the parasite Plasmodium. Over a hundred species have been described, but only P. falciparum, P. vivax, P. ovale, P. malariae, and P. knowlesi are known to commonly cause human infection. The disease is spread by the bite of the female Anopheles mosquito ( Fig. 6.2 ). Malaria can be divided clinically into uncomplicated and severe disease; most severe malaria is caused by P. falciparum. An estimated 219 million cases of malaria occurred worldwide in 2017, with 92% of these occurring in the WHO Africa Region. Nigeria had the greatest disease burden worldwide, with 25% of cases occurring there. There were 435,000 deaths globally, mostly in children under 5 years of age [ 49].
